The Medium Discourses

Chapter 7: King Dīrghāyu

This chapter of the Medium Discourses contains 15 sutras, beginning with its namesake, a lengthy sutra in which the Legend of King Dīrghāyu is embedded. Eight sutras have parallels in the Majjhima Nikāya, six in the Aṅguttara Nikāya, and one doesn’t appear to have a parallel.

English translations currently available with brief synopses of their contents are listed below. Pali equivalents are listed in () and the sourcetext is indicated in [].

72. The Legend of King Dīrghāyu (MN 128: Corruptions) [T 26.532c10]

The Buddha visits the monks in Kauśāmbī to find them quarrelling with each other constantly. He tells them the legend of King Dīrghāyu, a story about how a feud between two kings was ended, in an attempt to convince them to stop. Failing that, he leaves and travels alone. He meets with Venerable Bhagu, who was practicing alone in a temple grove. After a brief conversation, the Buddha goes to another grove to spend some time alone. There he meets an elephant who happens by after leaving his herd for some time alone. Finally, the Buddha travels to a grove where Venerable Aniruddha, Nandika, and Kimbila are living together and practicing meditation. He gives them a lengthy discourse on 11 things that impede deep concentration.

73. The Gods (AN 8.64: At Gāyā Head) [T 26.539b20]

Picking up where the Legend of King Dīrghāyu left off, the Buddha discusses his examination of the heavens using the knowledge gained in meditation. The production of light and seeing forms refers to using the divine eye to see the heavens.

74. Eight Thoughts (AN 8.30: Anuruddha and the Great Thoughts) [T 26.540c19]

Aniruddha has seven thoughts about how the path is obtained, and the Buddha visits him about it. Praising him, the Buddha suggests adding an eighth thought, and later he gives a discourse on the subject. Aniruddha becomes an arhat shortly thereafter.

75. The Pure Way to the Imperturbable (MN 106: Conducive to the Imperturbable) [T 26.542b4]

The Buddha explains the different mental orientations that lead to rebirth in the form and formless heavens, and how they differ from the orientation that leads to nirvāṇa.

76. [Ugracelā] (AN 8.63 and SN 47.3) [T 26.543c2]

While the Buddha was staying at [Ugracelā] on the Gaṅgā River, a monk requests a concise teaching from him. The Buddha outlines an intensive training program for the monk that consists of cultivating a wholesome mind, the four abodes of mindfulness, the three concentrations, and the four immeasurable minds. The monk becomes an arhat when he puts this into practice.

77. The Three Clansmen of Sāketa (MN 68: At Naḷakapāna) [T 26.544b22]

The Buddha checks how Aniruddha, Nandika, and Kimbila are doing shortly after they had become monks. When Aniruddha reports they are happy, the Buddha gives them a sermon, which includes an explanation of why he relates the rebirth of disciples after they die.

78. Brahmā Invites the Buddha (MN 49: On the Invitation of Brahmā) [T 26.547a11]

When Brahmā forms the wrong view that his heaven is the ultimate escape from suffering, the Buddha pays him a visit to correct this mistake. Māra Pāpīyān appears twice to try to derail the conversation between them.

79. The Greater Gods (MN 127: With Anuruddha) [T 26.549b5]

A laymen invites Aniruddha to visit for a meal and asks him a question on two different liberations of mind. Aniruddha resolves his question and then gives a discourse on three classes of gods in the Brahma Heaven.

80. The Rough Cloth [T 26.551c27]

Aniruddha asks for a new sets of robes, and Ānanda arranges a gathering of the monks to make them for him. The Buddha learns of this and joins them. When Aniruddha’s robes are complete, the Buddha retires with a backache, telling Aniruddha to give a lecture on the principle of the rough cloth for the 800 monks present. Aniruddha gives an outline of a monk’s training, which culiminates in attainment of the supernormal abilities, penetrating knowledges, and liberation.

81. Mindfulness of Body (MN 119: Mindfulness of the Body) [T 26.554c12]

The Buddha gives a description of 18 practices that constitute a monk’s mindfulness of body as well as the benefits that these practices bring.

82. Crickets (AN 6.60: With Hatthisāriputta) [T 26.557c17]

A monk named Citra [Hastisāriputra] causes trouble at a meeting of monks by interrupting the seniors monks and wranging with them. Mahākauṣṭhila was present and rebukes Citra for his behavior. When Citra's friends defend him, Mahākauṣṭhila gives them a teaching about how monks can attain a peaceful state of mind but then lose it because they revert to the desires of the lay life. Citra in the end chooses to return to the lay life.
